The Learning Lens: IX
Cincinnati, home-building experts
help viewers plan, build, or buy
homes. In the same city, traffic vio¬
lators receive cards advising them
to watch an etv safe-driving series.
The audience for the in-school
aspects of etv consists of students,
classroom teachers, school officials,
and the community. Even in ex¬
tremely cost-conscious communi¬
ties, etv is seldom promoted as a
tax-saving device. It is regarded
as one of many educational re¬
sources, along with school build¬
ings, teachers, and textbooks. After
a while, students begin to pay less
attention to the medium as such
and judge televised instruction
more on the basis of its quality.
And to teachers and school and col¬
lege administrators, etv is funda¬
mentally a versatile tool, only as
useful as the imagination and abil¬
ity of the people behind it.
